PLFS.description: Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) is a flagship labour data product under the category of Labour Statistics, conducted by the National Sample Survey Office (NSSO) to provide comprehensive insights into Indiaâ€™s employment and unemployment situation. Covering All India since 2017-18 to 2023-24, the survey is conducted annually and serves as the primary source for estimating major labour market indicators such as the Labour Force Participation Rate (LFPR), Worker Population Ratio (WPR), and Unemployment Rate (UR). The PLFS captures key dimensions of the labour market, including worker distribution by employment type, industry, education, gender, social group, and sector, as well as details on earnings, working hours, and employment conditions under both Usual Status (PS+SS) and Current Weekly Status (CWS). It also reports statistics such as the percentage of regular wage/salaried employees in the non-agriculture sector, average wage and earnings, and hours worked per week across diverse socio-economic and demographic filters. The survey follows the National Metadata Structure in compliance with metadata standards for the PLFS, ensuring harmonized and comparable estimates over time. The latest dataset was last updated on 23 September 2024, and future releases are scheduled as and when released by the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI).

indicators.name: LFPR (Labour Force Participation Rate, in per cent)
indicators.description: The Labour Force Participation Rate (LFPR) is the percentage of the population that is either working or actively seeking work. It is a key indicator of the supply of labour available for an economy's productive purposes. The LFPR is calculated for various age groups (e.g., 15 years and above), and its values are disaggregated by gender, education level, social category, and sector (rural/urban). The trend in LFPR, particularly among youth and women, is vital for understanding economic engagement, demographic dividend utilization, and the broad shifts in societal work norms. The survey uses different reference periods, such as Principal Status plus Subsidiary Status (PS+SS) or Current Weekly Status (CWS), to capture employment.

indicators.name: WPR (Worker Population Ratio, in per cent)
indicators.description: The Worker Population Ratio (WPR) is the percentage of the population that is employed or engaged in any economic activity. This metric directly measures the extent of employment within a given population segment. Like the LFPR, WPR is disaggregated by age, gender, education, and sector, and can be calculated based on Principal Status plus Subsidiary Status (PS+SS) or Current Weekly Status (CWS). A high or increasing WPR suggests greater economic activity and success in job creation. Tracking WPR across different demographic groups helps identify segments with low economic participation that may require targeted employment schemes.

indicators.name: UR (Unemployment Rate, in per cent)
indicators.description: The Unemployment Rate (UR) is the percentage of the labour force that is unemployed (i.e., those not working but actively seeking or available for work). It is a crucial measure of labour market efficiency and economic distress. The UR is calculated for various demographic and educational groups (e.g., highly educated youth) and is essential for monitoring the adequacy of job creation efforts relative to the demand for jobs. It is typically calculated using different reference criteria like Principal Status plus Subsidiary Status (PS+SS) or Current Weekly Status (CWS), providing varied perspectives on the severity of joblessness.

indicators.name: Percentage distribution of workers
indicators.description: This indicator provides a detailed breakdown of the employed population based on their industrial sector of work, status of employment, and the nature/size of the employing enterprise. It tracks the share of workers in the Primary (Agriculture), Secondary (Manufacturing, Construction), and Tertiary (Services) sectors, reflecting the structural transformation of the economy. Furthermore, it details the distribution by employment status (e.g., self-employed, regular wage/salaried, casual labour) and the type of enterprise (e.g., government, proprietary). This distribution is fundamental for understanding employment quality, informality levels, and the sectoral dependency of the workforce.

Industry Section: D_Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
E_Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities
G_Wholesale and retail trade; repair of motor vehicles and motorcycles
O_Public administration and defence compulsory social security

indicators.name: Percentage of regular wage/ salaried employees with employment condition as
indicators.description: This indicator provides a measure of job quality and social security coverage for the formal segment of the workforce (regular wage/salaried employees). It tracks the percentage of these workers who lack a written job contract, are not eligible for paid leave, or are without any social security benefits (SSB). These metrics highlight the precarious nature of employment and the degree of informality even within the salaried workforce, which is critical for evaluating the effectiveness of labour laws and social security schemes.

Employee Contract: 4.not eligible for paid leave, w.o. written job contract and w.o. any SSB

indicators.name: Average wage/salary earnings (Rs. 0.00) during the preceding calendar month from regular wage/salaried employment
indicators.description: This indicator measures the average monthly earnings in cash and kind for persons engaged in regular wage or salaried employment. This metric is a key indicator of income levels and standard of living for the stable workforce, often reflecting skill levels and productivity. The data is available by gender, sector, and state, enabling comparisons of earning disparities and regional economic performance. The availability of quarterly data allows for monitoring seasonal or short-term variations in earnings.

indicators.name: Average wage earnings (Rs. 0.00) per day from casual labour work other than public works
indicators.description: This indicator measures the average daily wage earned by individuals employed as casual labourers, excluding those on public works schemes. Casual labour is often characterized by low wages and high vulnerability, making this metric essential for measuring the minimum standard of living for the most marginalized workers and assessing the effectiveness of minimum wage policies. The disaggregated data by gender, sector, and quarter helps monitor wage gaps and temporal fluctuations.

indicators.name: Average gross earnings (Rs. 0.00) during last 30 days from self-employment
indicators.description: This indicator measures the average monthly gross earnings (income before expenses) of the self-employed population. Self-employment is a dominant employment status in India, and this metric is critical for assessing the profitability and viability of small and informal businesses and household enterprises. Analyzing this data by gender, sector, and state helps understand entrepreneurship trends and the economic resilience of the non-corporate sector.

ASUSE.description: All-India Survey of Unincorporated Non-Agricultural Enterprises (ASUSE) indicators covering enterprise characteristics, workers, and financial performance. The Annual Survey of Unincorporated Sector Enterprises (ASUSE) focuses on capturing the economic and operational characteristics of unincorporated non-agricultural establishments in manufacturing, trade, and services sectors.

IIP.description: The Index of Industrial Production (IIP) is a key statistical measure that tracks changes in the volume of production across different sectors of the economy. It provides monthly data on industrial growth for India, disaggregated by geography (All India, States, Rural, and Urban) and classified by sectoral output, 2-digit industry codes, and use-based categories. The index is compiled by comparing the current monthâ€™s production of selected items with the average monthly production in the designated base year. Multiple base periods are used for comparability over time: 1993-94, 2004-05, and 2011-12, with each revision reflecting updates in industrial structure and product coverage. The IIP dataset spans long historical seriesâ€”1994-95 to 2010-11 for the 1993-94 base, 2005-06 to 2016-17 for the 2004-05 base, and 2012-13 onwards for the 2011-12 base. Data are sourced from the Economic Statistics Division, Ministry of Statistics & Programme Implementation (MoSPI), and provide valuable insights into sectoral performance, industrial composition, and short-term economic fluctuations.

indicators.description: Captures industrial production trends between 1994-95 and 2010-11, reflecting the industrial structure of that era.

CPI.description: The Consumer Price Index (CPI), compiled by the Price Statistics Division, Ministry of Statistics & Programme Implementation, is the key measure of retail inflation in India. It tracks changes in the general level of retail prices of goods and services purchased by households for consumption. CPI and the Consumer Food Price Index (CFPI) are available at All India, Rural, Urban, and State levels, disaggregated by sector (Rural, Urban, Combined) to capture variations in household consumption. The series is available monthly from 2013 onwards (base 2012) and for the 2011â€“2014 period (base 2010), enabling consistent back series comparisons through linking factors. Coverage extends to all States and Union Territories, including major states like Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal, Kerala, Delhi, Maharashtra, and smaller regions such as Andaman & Nicobar, Ladakh, Lakshadweep, and Puducherry. The CPI dataset is structured around broad groups, subgroups, and items, including essential consumption categories such as Food and Beverages, Housing, Clothing and Footwear, Fuel and Light, and Miscellaneous. Within these, detailed subgroups (e.g., Cereals and Products, Pulses, Vegetables, Oils and Fats, Personal Care and Effects, Health, Education, Transport) and granular items (e.g., rice, wheat, pulses, milk, edible oils, fruits, vegetables, fish, eggs, meat, sugar, beverages, fuel, clothing, footwear, rent, medicines, transport services) are tracked. This layered structure allows users to study inflation trends at multiple levels of aggregationâ€”from broad groups down to specific commoditiesâ€”across time, month, sector, and geography. Key outputs include the Inflation Rate, Consumer Price Index, and Consumer Food Price Index, making CPI a foundational dataset for policy decisions, economic research, and price monitoring. The latest update is from 12 September 2025, with future releases aligned to the Advance Release Calendar 2025â€“26.

indicators.name: Group
indicators.description: The Group indicator organizes consumer goods and services into broad categories of household expenditure, such as Food and Beverages, Housing, Fuel and Light, Clothing and Footwear, Miscellaneous, and Consumer Food Price Index. Each group can be further broken into subgroups like Cereals, Pulses, Oils and Fats, Vegetables, Meat and Fish, Milk and Products, Education, Health, Transport, and Personal Care. This hierarchical structure helps in analyzing sectoral inflation trends across Indiaâ€™s states and union territories, covering regions from Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, and Maharashtra to smaller territories like Lakshadweep and Chandigarh. Users can explore monthly and annual movements from 2011 to 2025, across rural, urban, and combined sectors, with both current and back series available for continuity. By linking Group and Subgroup level indices, this indicator provides insights into broad inflationary pressures and their impact on household consumption patterns.

State: dadra and nagar haveli and daman and diu

indicators.name: Item
indicators.description: The Item indicator provides the most detailed level of CPI, tracking specific goods and services consumed by households. It captures price variations for hundreds of items such as cereals (rice, wheat, maize, millets), pulses (arhar, gram, moong), edible oils (mustard, groundnut, refined oils), milk and milk products (liquid milk, curd, ghee), fruits (banana, mango, apple, grapes), vegetables (potato, onion, tomato, leafy greens), meat and fish (chicken, mutton, prawn, crab), beverages (tea, coffee, fruit juices, cold drinks), processed foods (bread, biscuits, noodles, pickles, sweets), clothing, footwear, medicines, housing rents, transport fares, and personal care items. Data is available monthly from 2011 to 2025 across all states/UTs and rural, urban, combined sectors, enabling fine-grained tracking of commodity-level inflation. By analyzing the Item indicator, researchers and policymakers can identify price movements of essential goods, regional disparities in consumption costs, and inflationary pressures at the household level. This indicator is especially critical for targeted policy measures such as food subsidies, fuel pricing, or regional inflation monitoring.

ASI.description: The Annual Survey of Industries (ASI), conducted annually by the IS Wing of the Ministry of Statistics & Programme Implementation, is the principal source of industrial statistics in India covering registered manufacturing units across the country. The survey provides comprehensive information at All India and State-wise levels, capturing data on input, output, employment, fixed and working capital, assets, wages, depreciation, and value addition. The ASI dataset spans from 1992-93 to 2022-23 (excluding 1993-94), with classifications aligned to the National Industrial Classification (NIC) 1987, 1998, 2004, and 2008 to ensure consistency with evolving industrial structures. Users can analyze a wide range of industrial characteristics, including number of factories, persons engaged, wages & salaries, fuels consumed, gross and net value added, capital formation, profits, and productivity ratios. The database supports insights into time-series trends of industrial growth, structural ratios, and technical coefficients while allowing drilldowns by industry code (2-digit, 3-digit, and 4-digit NIC levels) and across states and union territories such as Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal, Delhi, and others. This makes ASI a critical statistical product for understanding Indiaâ€™s industrial development, workforce patterns, and regional industrial distribution.

indicators.description: The NIC-2008 indicators provide detailed measures of Indiaâ€™s industrial structure from 2008-09 to 2022-23, disaggregated by state/UT and NIC code levels (2-digit, 3-digit, 4-digit). Users can explore parameters such as number of factories, factories in operation, fixed capital, physical working capital, invested capital, outstanding loans, interest payments and receipts, depreciation, gross/net value added, gross capital formation, and net profit. Employment-related statistics include total persons engaged, directly employed workers (male, female, children), workers employed through contractors, and supervisory/managerial staff. Data also extends to wages and salaries (with bonuses and employer contributions), total emoluments, and welfare expenses. For production and consumption, the indicators cover value of output, value of by-products, fuels consumed (coal, electricity, petroleum products, and other fuels), as well as stocks of semi-finished and finished goods. This set facilitates in-depth time-series and regional analysis of industrial performance under the NIC-2008 framework.

indicators.description: The NIC-2004 indicators span 2004-05 to 2007-08, enabling longitudinal industrial comparisons under the NIC 2004 classification system. The framework is similar to NIC-2008, covering production, input, output, wages, capital structure, and employment dimensions, but aligned to the older classification for consistency with earlier periods. State-wise disaggregation allows analysis of industrial concentration across regions, while NIC levels (2-digit, 3-digit, and 4-digit) support industry-specific breakdowns. This series is particularly useful for bridging data continuity between NIC-1998 and NIC-2008 classifications, ensuring comparative industrial analysis across reforms and structural shifts in Indiaâ€™s economy.

indicators.description: The NIC-1998 series provides ASI data for 2003-04 to 1998-99, offering continuity from earlier classification standards. It includes core industrial variables such as number of factories, fixed and working capital, invested capital, wages, depreciation, output, and value addition. Detailed insights into employment composition by gender, contractual workers, managerial staff, and unpaid family workers are included, alongside financial performance indicators like gross/net income and profits. The dataset also enables fuel consumption studies (coal, petroleum, electricity, other fuels), useful for tracking industrial energy dependence. State and NIC-level breakdowns ensure fine-grained exploration of sectoral dynamics within the NIC-1998 classification.

It mirrors the same dimensions as later NIC classifications, capturing capital formation, industrial production, employment, wages, input-output structures, and fuel consumption, but structured under NIC-1987 categories. This dataset is particularly relevant for long-run trend analysis of Indiaâ€™s industrialization, allowing researchers to compare data over multiple decades while acknowledging classification shifts. The NIC-1987 series thus supports historical benchmarking of industrial statistics at both state and national levels.

TUS.description: Time Use Survey (TUS) is a flagship product under the National Sample Survey conducted by the National Statistics Office (NSO), Ministry of Statistics & Programme Implementation, covering All India, States/UTs, Rural and Urban areas. Conducted during Januaryâ€“December 2024, following the earlier round in 2019, the survey is undertaken as and when the requirement arises to provide a comprehensive understanding of how individuals aged 6 years and above allocate their time across various productive and non-productive activities. The TUS collects data on participation and time spent in paid employment, unpaid caregiving and domestic work, volunteer services, learning, socializing, leisure, and self-care activities, enabling measurement of both SNA (System of National Accounts) and Non-SNA activities. Key statistics include participation rates (%), average time spent per participant or per person (in minutes) across paid, unpaid, and other activities, and their distribution by socio-demographic and economic characteristics such as gender, marital status, age group, education, social group, and household consumption quintile. The 2019 and 2024 TUS rounds adhere to the National Metadata Structure and comply with the metadata standards for unit-level data of TUS. The dataset includes detailed indicators on percentage and time spent across activities as major and non-major activities, disaggregated by factors such as usual principal activity status, marital status, UMPCE quintile class, education level, social group, and day type. The most recent dataset was last updated on 31 March 2025, with future releases to be published as and when released by the Ministry.

Gender.description: Women and Men in India, 2024 is an annual publication released by the Social Statistics Division of the Ministry of Statistics & Programme Implementation. Covering All India, Rural, Urban, and State/UT levels, it consolidates demographic, economic, social, health, education, and decision-making indicators. This report is a centralized resource on gender statistics, presenting comparative profiles of women and men while also highlighting barriers to empowerment. It draws on multiple data sources to enable policymakers, researchers, and civil society actors to assess progress in gender equality and track disparities across regions. The 2024 edition was last updated on 31st March 2025 and is scheduled for its next release in March 2026.

indicators.name: Trend in Population
indicators.description: This indicator presents the population trends in India across sectors (rural and urban) by gender. It highlights shifts in the demographic structure over time, providing insights into gender distribution and sector-wise population growth. Annual time series help assess how population dynamics vary by region and gender.

indicators.name: Sex Ratio
indicators.description: The sex ratio indicator measures the number of females per 1,000 males across States and Union Territories. It serves as a critical demographic measure of gender balance, reflecting the social and cultural dimensions that affect survival and well-being of women and men.

indicators.name: Average Annual Growth Rate of Population
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the average annual rate of population increase, disaggregated by gender. It shows how male and female populations grow over the years, offering insights into demographic momentum and the potential implications for planning and resource allocation.

indicators.name: Percentage Distribution of Projected Population
indicators.description: This measure captures the age-group wise distribution of projected population by gender. It provides a forward-looking picture of demographic shifts, useful for planning education, employment, and healthcare services tailored to different age and gender groups.

indicators.name: Sex ratio in context of developmental planning
indicators.description: This indicator shows the sex ratio across age groups and States/UTs, highlighting how demographic balance differs within younger and older populations. Such insights are crucial for development policies, as they reflect gender equity in survival and access to healthcare.

indicators.name: State-wise Sex Ratio
indicators.description: State-wise Sex Ratio

indicators.name: Sex ratio at birth for bigger States based on Sample Registration System
indicators.description: Derived from the Sample Registration System, this indicator focuses on sex ratio at birth across larger States and sectors (rural/urban). It highlights patterns of gender bias at birth and helps monitor improvements or setbacks in reducing gender-based selection.

indicators.name: General Fertility Rate
indicators.description: This indicator reports the number of live births per 1,000 women of reproductive age, classified by education level of women and sector. By linking fertility patterns with education, it underscores how women's educational attainment influences reproductive behavior.

indicators.name: Age-specific Fertility rate
indicators.description: This measure provides fertility rates by age group of women and sector, disaggregated by gender of the child. It highlights the reproductive behavior of women at different ages, helping policymakers assess teenage pregnancies, peak fertility years, and delayed motherhood.

indicators.name: Total Fertility Rate
indicators.description: Total Fertility Rate

indicators.name: Percentage distribution of live births
indicators.description: This indicator presents the percentage distribution of live births classified by birth order, providing critical insights into fertility behavior and reproductive health patterns across different years and sectors. By tracking the frequency of first, second, and higher-order births, it allows policymakers to analyze trends in family planning practices, intergenerational spacing, and maternal health.

indicators.name: Adolescent Fertility Rates
indicators.description: This indicator measures fertility rates among adolescent women, offering a lens into early childbearing patterns. Disaggregated by year, sector, and state/UT, the dataset enables comparative analysis across geographies and time. High adolescent fertility often correlates with reduced educational opportunities, higher maternal and child health risks, and social inequality, making it a vital demographic and health indicator.

indicators.name: Age Specific Fertility Rate by level of education of women
indicators.description: This indicator provides fertility rates by age group and education level, highlighting how educational attainment shapes reproductive behavior. The inclusion of sectoral classifications further enriches the analysis, allowing researchers to link fertility transitions with socioeconomic status. Such data is instrumental in understanding the role of female education in reducing fertility rates and improving maternal and child health outcomes.

indicators.name: Women's Mean Age at Marriage
indicators.description: This indicator captures the mean age at which women marry across states/UTs, sectors, and years, reflecting shifts in social norms and their health implications. Early marriage is often associated with higher fertility, maternal health risks, and limited educational attainment. Tracking changes in mean marriage age thus provides insights into gender equality and empowerment trajectories.

indicators.name: Year Wise Infant Mortality Rate
indicators.description: This indicator records the infant mortality rate (IMR) by gender and year, offering an essential measure of child health outcomes. The indicator helps identify disparities in survival rates among male and female infants, while temporal analysis highlights improvements or stagnation in healthcare access, immunization, and maternal care.

indicators.name: State/UT  Wise Infant Mortality Rate
indicators.description: State/UT  Wise Infant Mortality Rate

indicators.name: Under-Five Mortality Rates (U5MR)
indicators.description: This indicator provides mortality rates for children under the age of five, disaggregated by gender, state/UT, and year. U5MR is a key Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) metric, reflecting the overall effectiveness of child health interventions. Gender-based breakdowns highlight inequalities in survival outcomes, while state-level analysis aids localized policymaking.

indicators.name: Year Wise Life Expectancy at birth
indicators.description: The indicator tracks life expectancy at birth by gender across years, offering a fundamental measure of population health and longevity. Differences between male and female life expectancy highlight biological, behavioral, and social factors influencing survival. Temporal patterns provide evidence of improvements in healthcare, nutrition, and living standards.

indicators.name: State/UT  wise Life Expectancy at birth
indicators.description: State/UT  wise Life Expectancy at birth

indicators.name: Life Expectation at age 60
indicators.description: Focusing on survival beyond older adulthood, this indicator captures life expectancy at age 60 by gender, state/UT, and year. It highlights aging patterns, longevity improvements, and the impact of healthcare systems on elderly populations. Such data is critical for designing policies on geriatric healthcare, pensions, and social security.

indicators.name: Maternal Mortality Ratio
indicators.description: The indicator measures maternal deaths per 100,000 live births across states/UTs and years, serving as a crucial measure of maternal health and healthcare system effectiveness. High MMR reflects gaps in antenatal care, delivery services, and emergency obstetric interventions, making it central to monitoring SDG progress on maternal health.

indicators.name: Maternity Care Indicators
indicators.description: This composite indicator includes multiple sub-indicators on maternity care services, disaggregated by state/UT, survey type, and year. It provides evidence on access to antenatal checkups, institutional deliveries, postnatal care, and maternal health outcomes. Such granular information supports both cross-state benchmarking and time-series evaluations.

Sub Indicator: Mothers who  consumed iron folic acid for 100 days or  more when  they were pregnant (%)
Mothers who had antenatal check-up in the first trimester (%)
Mothers who had at least 4 antenatal care  visits (%)
Percentage of deliveries with a postnatal health check for the mother within 2 days of birth*

State Ut: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Percentage of Births Attended by Skilled Health Personnel
indicators.description: This indicator measures the share of live births attended by trained health professionals across states/UTs, surveys, years, and sub-indicators. It directly reflects progress in safe delivery practices, maternal health care availability, and health system capacity.

Sub Indicator: Home births that were conducted by skilled health personnel (%)

State Ut: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Percentage of married women use any modern method of family planning
indicators.description: This indicator provides the percentage of married women adopting modern contraceptive methods, disaggregated by family planning method, state/UT, survey, and year. It reflects family planning coverage and choices, offering insights into reproductive autonomy and policy effectiveness.

State Ut: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.description: Unmet Need for Family Planning

indicators.description: Current tobacco use (15years or above)

State Ut: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Proportion of Adults who are Obese (BMI >= 30.0)
indicators.description: This indicator captures the prevalence of obesity among adults, defined by BMI 30.0, across gender, state/UT, survey sources, and years. It reflects the rising burden of non-communicable diseases and lifestyle changes, enabling targeted interventions in obesity prevention and management.

State Ut: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Number of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected population
indicators.description: This indicator records the incidence of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected individuals, disaggregated by gender, state/UT, and year. It is a critical indicator for assessing HIV transmission trends, program effectiveness, and progress toward epidemic control.

State Ut: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Number of PLHIV alive and on ART at the end of January 2025
indicators.description: This indicator reports the number of People Living with HIV (PLHIV) alive and receiving Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) at a given point, such as January 2025. Disaggregated by gender, state/UT, and sub-indicators, it measures treatment coverage, survival outcomes, and the strength of HIV care systems.

indicators.name: Cases and Deaths due to Acute Diarrhoeal Diseases
indicators.description: This indicator provides the reported number of cases and deaths attributed to acute diarrhoeal diseases, broken down by gender, state/UT, year, and sub-indicator. It is essential for monitoring infectious disease outbreaks, public health responses, and improvements in sanitation and clean water access.

indicators.name: Cases and Deaths due to Cholera Infection
indicators.description: Tracking cholera-related cases and deaths, this indicator is disaggregated by gender, state/UT, year, and sub-indicator. It helps assess epidemic trends, water safety, and emergency response capacity across regions.

indicators.name: Cases and Deaths due to Enteric Fever (Typhoid) Infection
indicators.description: This indicator documents cases and deaths due to typhoid infection, classified by gender, state/UT, year, and sub-indicator. It highlights disease burden linked to waterborne pathogens and supports the evaluation of vaccination and public health measures.

indicators.name: Cases and Deaths due to Acute Respiratory Infection
indicators.description: This indicator captures morbidity and mortality from acute respiratory infections across gender, state/UT, year, and sub-indicators. It reflects seasonal epidemic patterns and helps evaluate the effectiveness of respiratory disease prevention programs.

indicators.name: Cases and Deaths due to Neonatal Tentanus Infection
indicators.description: Cases and Deaths due to Neonatal Tentanus Infection

indicators.name: Cases and Deaths due to Tetanus Infection
indicators.description: This indicator measures tetanus morbidity and mortality outside the neonatal context, categorized by gender, state/UT, year, and sub-indicator. It reflects the broader impact of vaccination and trauma-related infection control.

indicators.name: Cases and Deaths due to Diphtheria Infection
indicators.description: This indicator presents diphtheria-related cases and deaths, disaggregated by gender, state/UT, year, and sub-indicator. It is vital for monitoring vaccine-preventable diseases and assessing immunization program performance.

indicators.name: Cases and Deaths due to Whooping Cough infection
indicators.description: Cases and Deaths due to Whooping Cough infection

indicators.name: Cases and Deaths due to Measles Infection
indicators.description: This indicator documents measles cases and deaths, disaggregated by gender, state/UT, year, and sub-indicator. It remains central to assessing immunization progress, outbreak preparedness, and child health outcomes.

indicators.name: Women undergone a screening test for cervical cancer and breast cancer (%)
indicators.description: This indicator measures the percentage of women who have undergone screening for cervical and breast cancer, providing insights into preventive healthcare access and utilization. The data are classified by sector, state/UT, and sub-indicators, enabling an assessment of disparities in women's health awareness, healthcare outreach, and early detection services.

Sub Indicator: Ever undergone a breast examination for breast cancer (%)
Ever undergone a screening test for cervical cancer (%)

State Ut: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Women who have comprehensive knowledge of HIV/AIDS (%)
indicators.description: This indicator captures the proportion of women with comprehensive knowledge about HIV/AIDS transmission and prevention, disaggregated by state/UT, survey source, and year. It reflects the reach of awareness programs, the effectiveness of health communication strategies, and regional gaps in sexual and reproductive health education.

indicators.name: Women whose Body Mass Index is below normal and who are overweight or obese
indicators.description: Women whose Body Mass Index is below normal and who are overweight or obese

indicators.name: Literacy Rates for persons aged 7 years and above
indicators.description: This indicator measures literacy levels among individuals aged 7 years and above, disaggregated by gender, sector, and year. It provides an overarching picture of educational attainment and highlights gender and sectoral differences in literacy.

indicators.name: Gender Gap in Literacy Rate for persons of age 7 years and above
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the gap between male and female literacy rates among individuals aged 7 years and above. It is categorized by gender, sector, survey source, and year, enabling assessments of progress toward gender equality in education.

indicators.name: State/UT wise Gender Gap in Literacy Rate for persons of age 7 years and above
indicators.description: This indicator disaggregates the literacy gender gap data at the state/UT level, further classified by sector. It helps identify regions with persistent inequalities and supports state-level education policy interventions.

indicators.name: Literacy Rate of Youth in the Age Group of 15-24 Years
indicators.description: This dataset measures literacy rates among youth aged 15-24 years, categorized by gender, state/UT, and year. It is a key indicator of progress toward universal education and reflects the effectiveness of recent educational initiatives targeting adolescents and young adults.

indicators.name: Percentage of persons able to read and write short simple statements
indicators.description: This indicator measures functional literacy, defined as the ability to read and write short, simple statements. It is disaggregated by gender, sector, and state/UT, highlighting the foundational literacy levels across demographic groups and regions.

State Ut: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Gross Enrolment Ratio
indicators.description: This indicator represents the total enrolment in a given level of education (regardless of age) expressed as a percentage of the official school-age population for that level. Classified by education level, gender, and year, GER provides a measure of the reach of educational systems across demographic groups.

indicators.name: Adjusted Net Enrolment Rate
indicators.description: This dataset reports the proportion of children of official school age who are enrolled in that level of education, adjusted to account for over-aged and under-aged students. The indicator is available by education level, gender, and year, offering a refined measure of schooling participation.

indicators.name: Gender Parity Index (GPI)
indicators.description: Gender Parity Index (GPI)

indicators.name: Gender Parity Index (GPI-As Per NEP Structure)
indicators.description: Gender Parity Index (GPI-As Per NEP Structure)

indicators.name: Gender Parity Indices (GPI) in Higher Education
indicators.description: This indicator focuses on gender parity in higher education enrolments, disaggregated by state/UT and year. It highlights gender equity in tertiary education and helps assess the inclusiveness of higher education systems.

indicators.name: Enrolment at Under Graduate Level
indicators.description: Enrolment at Under Graduate Level

indicators.name: Enrolment at Ph.D., M.Phil. & Post Graduate Level
indicators.description: Enrolment at Ph.D., M.Phil. & Post Graduate Level

indicators.name: Female-Male Ratio in Important Programmes - Regular Mode of Education
indicators.description: This indicator provides the female-to-male ratio in key academic programmes under the regular mode of education. Disaggregated by education level and year, it serves as an important gender parity measure, reflecting inclusivity in higher education.

indicators.name: Average years completed in formal education (pre-primary or above)
indicators.description: This indicator reports the average number of years individuals spend in formal education from pre-primary onwards. The data is segmented by age group, gender, and sector, offering a profile of educational attainment across population cohorts.

indicators.name: Mean years of schooling in formal education (including pre-primary level of education)
indicators.description: This indicator represents the mean duration of schooling completed by individuals, counting from pre-primary education upwards. It is categorized by age group, gender, and sector, helping to assess long-term progress in educational attainment.

indicators.name: Mean years of schooling in formal education (15 years and above)
indicators.description: This indicator captures the mean years of schooling for individuals aged 15 years and above. The data, disaggregated by gender, sector, and State/UT, reflects disparities in access to and completion of education among older youth and adults.

State Ut: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Mean years of schooling in formal education (25 years and above)
indicators.description: This indicator measures the mean schooling years completed by individuals aged 25 years and above. Disaggregated by gender, sector, and State/UT, it reveals generational progress and educational inequalities across different states.

State Ut: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Population with at least secondary as the highest level of education successfully completed
indicators.description: This indicator shows the proportion of the population whose highest completed level of education is at least secondary school. Gender and State/UT classifications allow for comparative analysis of secondary attainment rates across regions.

State Ut: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Examination Result Level-wise Out-turn/Pass out in Higher Education
indicators.description: Examination Result Level-wise Out-turn/Pass out in Higher Education

indicators.name: Dropout Rate
indicators.description: This indicator tracks dropout rates at various levels of education. Disaggregated by education level, gender, and year, it serves as a critical measure of student retention, helping to assess systemic challenges in continuing education.

indicators.name: Average expenditure (Rs.) per student pursuing general course
indicators.description: This indicator reports the average expenditure per student enrolled in general education courses. It is categorized by education level, gender, and sector, offering insights into resource allocation and cost disparities in general education.

indicators.name: Average expenditure (Rs.) per student in basic course
indicators.description: Average expenditure (Rs.) per student in basic course

indicators.name: Number of Female Teachers per 100 Male Teachers
indicators.description: This indicator presents the number of female teachers per 100 male teachers, providing a gender ratio measure within teaching staff. Classified by education level and year, it highlights gender representation in the teaching workforce.

indicators.name: Proportion of females among tertiary education teachers or professors

NAS.description: The National Accounts Statistics (NAS) provide an integrated statistical framework for measuring the economic performance of India, compiled by the National Accounts Division, MoSPI. Covering the period 2011-12 onwards for the current series and 1950-51 to 2011-12 for the back series, NAS offers both annual and quarterly estimates at the all-India level. The data are derived from diverse sources including administrative records, tax data, censuses, sample surveys, and sectoral statistics, aligned to the System of National Accounts (SNA) methodology. The base year currently used is 2011-12, with estimates revised systematically through first advance, provisional, and final revisions. NAS delivers key macroeconomic indicators such as Gross Domestic Product (GDP), Gross Value Added (GVA), Gross and Net National Income, Consumption Expenditure (private and government), Gross Fixed Capital Formation (GFCF), Imports, Exports, Gross Saving, and Capital Formation. Sectoral disaggregation is extensive, spanning agriculture and allied activities, manufacturing industries, construction, trade, transport, communication, mining, electricity and utilities, financial services, real estate, public administration, defence, and other services. Institutional sector accounts are also compiled for households, government, financial and non-financial corporations, and NPISH (Non-Profit Institutions Serving Households). The back series (1950-51 to 2011-12) ensures long-term comparability of estimates, enabling robust macroeconomic analysis.

indicators.name: Series
indicators.description: This indicator provides estimates of key macroeconomic aggregates such as Gross Value Added, GDP, Net Taxes on Products, Subsidies, Gross Capital Formation, Consumption Expenditure, Imports, Exports, Gross National Disposable Income, and Gross Saving, reported annually and quarterly. Estimates are available across industries and sub-industries (e.g., crops, livestock, forestry, food processing, textiles, railways, financial services, real estate, public administration, etc.) as well as by institutional sectors (public/private corporations, government, households, NPISH). Data spans from 2011-12 onwards, with multiple revision stages (advance estimates to final) ensuring accuracy. Growth rates such as GDP growth rate and GVA growth rate are also provided for sectoral and aggregate levels.

Indicator: Gross Capital Formation by Industry of Use

indicators.name: Back
indicators.description: The back-series indicator extends the NAS to 1950-51 through 2011-12, providing annual estimates for aggregates including GVA, GDP, Capital Formation, Consumption of Fixed Capital, Private and Government Expenditure, Gross National Income, and Gross Saving. Industry-level details are preserved for agriculture, manufacturing, services, trade, transport, and utilities, making it possible to track Indiaâ€™s structural transformation over seven decades. This series allows researchers and policymakers to analyze long-run economic growth, sectoral shifts, and macroeconomic policy impacts across different historical phases.

NSS78.description: The NSS 78th Round: Multiple Indicator Survey (MIS) in India (2020â€“21), conducted by the National Sample Survey Office (NSSO), MoSPI, was designed primarily to generate national-level indicators for tracking the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Beyond SDG indicators, the survey also collected information on housing (purchase/construction since 2014), migration particulars, access to mass media, internet connectivity, household sanitation, drinking water availability, transport and public facilities, and household assets. The survey provides state-wise and all-India data and is released as and when required, with the last update published on 7 March 2023. Key statistics include the percentage of households with access to improved sanitation and clean fuel, access to safe drinking water, digital inclusion, reasons for migration, and changes in household income due to migration, making it an important evidence base for policy planning in housing, infrastructure, and welfare schemes.

indicators.name: Usage of mobile phone
indicators.description: This indicator measures the percentage of individuals using mobile phones, disaggregated by age group, gender, state, and sector (rural/urban). It provides insights into digital access and gender or age-based disparities in connectivity across regions.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Access to Mass Media and Broadband
indicators.description: This indicator captures household and individual access to mass media (TV, radio, print) and broadband/Internet connectivity, filtered by internet access status, state, and ruralâ€“urban sector. It reflects patterns of information access and digital penetration.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Main reason for leaving last usual place of residence
indicators.description: This indicator identifies the primary reasons for migration, including work, education, marriage, or other socio-economic factors. It is disaggregated by gender, migration reason, state, and sector, helping to understand migration drivers across demographic groups.

Migration Reason: Migration of parent/earning member of the family
To take up employment / better employment
Social/political problems (riots, terrorism, political refugee, bad law and order, etc.)

indicators.name: Improved latrine and hand washing facilities within household

It is classified by state and sector, highlighting regional disparities in sanitation and hygiene.

indicators.name: Exclusive access to improved latrine

indicators.name: Income Change due to Migration
indicators.description: This indicator measures the change in household income after migration, showing whether income increased, decreased, or remained the same compared to the last place of residence. It is presented by state and sector, offering insights into the economic impact of migration.

indicators.name: Improved source of drinking water within household

It is broken down by state and sector, reflecting progress toward safe water access.

NSS77.description: The NSS 77th Round (Situation Assessment of Agricultural Households and Land and Livestock Holdings of Households in Rural India, 2019), conducted by the National Sample Survey Office (MoSPI), provides a detailed statistical profile of agricultural households in rural India. Covering the period January to December 2019, the survey collected information on farm business receipts and expenditures, non-farm activities, access to technical advice, indebtedness, insurance coverage, crop losses, and household socio-economic conditions. It also examined land ownership, operational holdings, leasing arrangements, and livestock ownership patterns. The data are disaggregated at all-India and state levels and classified by household type, land possessed, social group, operational/ownership holdings, and sources of income. Released in September 2021, the findings serve as a key reference for understanding rural livelihoods, farming sustainability, and household-level vulnerabilities in Indiaâ€™s agrarian economy.

indicators.name: Estimated No. of Hhs for Each Size Class (ha.) of Land Possessed
indicators.description: This indicator provides estimates of rural and agricultural households classified by size class of land possessed, further disaggregated by household classification and state. The data help capture the landholding structure of rural India across farm size categories, reflecting agrarian distribution patterns.

indicators.name: Estimated No. of Hhs for Different Social Groups
indicators.description: This indicator gives the estimated number of agricultural households across social groups such as SC, ST, OBC, and Others, filtered by household classification and state. It highlights the social composition of rural agrarian households.

indicators.name: Distribution of Hhs by Hh Classification for Different Size Classes of Land Possessed
indicators.description: This indicator shows how agricultural households are distributed by household classification, social group, and employment characteristics, combined with land possessed and state. It captures the intersection of landholding, caste, and employment.

indicators.name: No. Per Hh Operational Holding by Size Class of Hh Operational Holding
indicators.description: This indicator presents the number of agricultural households per operational holding size class, disaggregated by household classification, social group, season, and state. It reflects operational land distribution in rural India.

indicators.description: This indicator provides the distribution of crop-producing households disposing crops through different agencies, along with their satisfaction levels regarding sale outcomes. Disaggregated by state and season, it highlights farmer-market interactions and price realization.

indicators.name: Agricultural Hhs Reporting Use of Purchased Seed by their Quality

indicators.name: Avg. Monthly Income (in Rs.) Per Agricultural Hh (only the Paid Out Expenditure)
indicators.description: This indicator measures the average monthly income of agricultural households, considering only paid-out expenditures, disaggregated by social group, land possessed, source of income, season, and state. It shows real earnings net of imputed costs.

indicators.name: Avg. Monthly Expenses and Receipts for Crop Production

indicators.name: Average Expenses and Receipts From Non-farm Business

ESI.description: Energy Statistics India (2023â€“24), published annually by the Economic Statistics Division, MoSPI, provides a comprehensive national database on Indiaâ€™s energy sector. It covers the reserves, installed capacity, production, imports, exports, stock changes, and consumption of all major energy commodities, including coal, lignite, crude oil, natural gas, oil products, hydro, nuclear, electricity, and renewable sources such as solar and wind. The report aligns with international statistical standards and contains Energy Balance tables (in Kilo Tonnes of Oil Equivalent and PetaJoules), Energy Accounts, Sankey diagrams, and sustainable energy indicators. The publication serves as a vital reference for understanding Indiaâ€™s energy supply-demand dynamics, sectoral allocation, and transition to renewable energy sources, with the latest update in March 2025 and an annual release cycle every March.

indicators.name: Energy Balance (in KToE)
indicators.description: The Energy Balance (in Kilo Tonnes of Oil Equivalent) provides a consolidated account of Indiaâ€™s energy flows expressed in a common unit, KToE. It includes supply-side elements such as production, imports, exports, and stock changes, along with consumption patterns across end-use sectors. Users can filter the data by year (2012â€“13 to 2023â€“24), by energy commodity (coal, lignite, crude oil, natural gas, oil products, hydro, nuclear, electricity, solar, wind, and other renewables, as well as total energy), and by end-use sectors (exports, imports, production, stock changes, and total primary energy supply). This indicator enables long-term tracking of Indiaâ€™s energy security, self-reliance, and dependency on imports.

indicators.name: Energy Balance (in PetaJoules)
indicators.description: The Energy Balance (in PetaJoules) expresses the same framework of Indiaâ€™s energy system but in PetaJoules (PJ), an internationally used unit for cross-country comparability. It provides detailed statistics on production, imports, exports, supply, and final consumption, with the same disaggregation available by year (2012â€“13 to 2023â€“24), energy commodities, and end-use sectors as in the KToE balance. This indicator is particularly relevant for researchers and policymakers who require harmonized energy accounting in physical energy units, supporting global energy comparisons and sustainability assessments.

CPI-AL&RL.description: The Agricultural Labourers and Rural Labourers Consumer Price Index (CPI-AL/RL) are monthly indices compiled by the Labour Bureau, Ministry of Labour & Employment, that measure changes in the retail prices of goods and services consumed by agricultural and rural labour households. With a base year of 1986â€“87, the index tracks inflation trends from 1999â€“2000 onwards, covering 20 major states and selected districts. CPI-AL: Represents households of agricultural labourers. CPI-RL: Represents households of rural labourers (including agricultural labourers). These indices are central to monitoring the cost of living, wage adjustment, and rural poverty trends in India.

indicators.name: General Index
indicators.description: The General Index provides the overall Consumer Price Index for agricultural and rural labour households, reflecting the combined effect of all commodity and service groups in the consumption basket. It can be disaggregated by year, month, and state, enabling analysis of inflation trends across time and regions. This index serves as a benchmark for understanding headline rural inflation.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Group Index
indicators.description: The Group Index measures consumer price movements within specific expenditure groups. This indicator allows granular tracking of price pressures faced by agricultural and rural labour households. With filters for year, month, state, and group, it supports comparative analysis of consumption patterns and price variation across regions and categories.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

HCES.description: The Household Consumption Expenditure Survey (HCES), conducted by the Household Survey Division of MoSPI, provides nationally representative data on household consumption patterns in rural and urban India. Covering both food and non-food items, the survey captures quantity consumed, value spent, and frequency of purchase at the household level. Its outputs include measures of Monthly Per Capita Consumption Expenditure (MPCE) and its distribution across categories, states/UTs, and socio-economic groups.

indicators.name: Average monthly per capita consumption expenditure (MPCE)
indicators.description: This indicator provides the mean value of monthly household expenditure per person, serving as a core welfare measure. Results can be filtered by survey year, geography, rural/urban sector, and imputation methodology, offering a baseline measure of household living conditions.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Average monthly per capita consumption expenditure (MPCE) Over 12 Fractile Classes
indicators.description: This indicator disaggregates MPCE across 12 fractile classes (percentile-based expenditure groups), highlighting distributional differences. Data can be compared across states/UTs, years, and ruralâ€“urban sectors, making it crucial for poverty and inequality profiling.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Monthly Per Capita Consumption Expenditure (MPCE) over Broad Categories in 30 Days
indicators.description: This indicator details household spending by item category (e.g., food, fuel, education, health, clothing, durable goods). It provides both absolute expenditure and allows differentiation by imputation type, state/UT, rural/urban sector, and year, enabling sectoral consumption analysis.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Percentage Share of Monthly Per Capita Consumption Expenditure (MPCE) over Broad Categories in 30 Days
indicators.description: This indicator reports the proportion of household expenditure allocated to each broad category, showing consumption priorities. It enables welfare comparisons by examining shifts in budget shares across food, non-food, and services.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Average Per Capita Monthly Quantity Consumption
indicators.description: This indicator reports the average monthly per capita physical consumption (in kg/litre/units) of various commodities, with a focus on cereals. It allows disaggregation by survey year, state/UT, and ruralâ€“urban sector, enabling comparisons of dietary intake patterns across regions and over time.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Average Monthly Per Capita Value of Consumption (Rs.)
indicators.description: This indicator captures the average rupee value of monthly cereal consumption per person, allowing both physical and monetary assessment of food expenditure. It supports comparisons by year, region, and ruralâ€“urban sector.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Average Monthly Per Capita Consumption Expenditure (MPCE) across different Household Type
indicators.description: This indicator presents household expenditure patterns by employment type of the household head (e.g., self-employed, regular wage/salaried, casual labour, others). It highlights differences in welfare outcomes across occupational groups.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Average Monthly Per Capita Consumption Expenditure (MPCE) across different Social Group
indicators.description: This indicator reports MPCE across social groups such as Scheduled Castes (SC), Scheduled Tribes (ST), Other Backward Classes (OBC), and Others, enabling disaggregated analysis of social disparities in consumption levels.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Gini Coefficient for Per Capita Consumption Expenditure
indicators.description: This indicator measures inequality in household consumption expenditure using the Gini coefficient. It can be analyzed by state/UT, ruralâ€“urban sector, and whether data are based on imputed or reported values, supporting insights into disparities in living standards.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

EC.description: The Economic Census provides the count of establishments involved in economic activities (excluding those engaged in crop production and plantation), including those in unorganized sector. It is a data source providing data on number of establishments in the country, number of persons employed therein along with their distribution by geographical location, type of ownership, etc.
