ENVSTAT.description: EnviStats India: Environment Statistics   is a comprehensive statistical product within the domain of   Environment Statistics  , compiled and disseminated by the   Social Statistics Division   of the   Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI)  . It provides a systematic compilation of data on the environment and related factors across   All India   and   State/UT levels  , with the objective of facilitating a deeper understanding of environmental trends, their spatial variations, and the underlying drivers of change. Published on an   annual basis  , the   2025 edition   continues MoSPIâ€™s commitment to delivering reliable and policy-relevant environmental data. The   primary purpose   of the EnviStats India series is to present structured information on the   state of the environment  , its   changes over time  , and the   key factors influencing these changes  . It is designed to support   evidence-based policymaking  ,   sustainable development planning  , and   public awareness  , serving the needs of policymakers, researchers, and the general public alike. The publication compiles a broad set of   key environmental indicators  , including   annual mean temperature  ,   annual rainfall  ,   faunal diversity  ,   fish production  ,   watersheds  ,   catchment areas of major river basins  , and   length of coastline  , among others. These indicators capture the interlinkages between environmental resources, biodiversity, and human activity, offering an integrated statistical view of Indiaâ€™s environmental landscape. The dataset was   last updated on 5 June 2025  , with future releases scheduled   as per the Advance Release Calendar  . While no fixed base period is applied, EnviStats adheres to internationally recognized frameworks for environmental accounting and data quality. The detailed methodological and structural documentation is available through the   National Metadata Structure  , in compliance with the   Metadata of EnviStats India Volume I: Environment Statistics  , ensuring transparency, comparability, and alignment with global statistical standards.

indicators.name: Annual and Seasonal Mean Temperature
indicators.description: This indicator provides the average temperature for India, segmented by year and specific seasons. It is essential for analyzing long-term climate trends, identifying potential impacts of climate change, and understanding seasonal thermal variations across the country. The data is available annually and for four distinct seasonal periods: winter (Jan-Feb), pre-monsoon (Mar-May), monsoon (June-Sept), and post-monsoon (Oct-Dec), allowing for detailed temporal analysis.

indicators.name: Annual and Seasonal Minimum and Maximum Temperature
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the extreme temperature boundaries for India, detailing the annual and seasonal minimum and maximum temperatures. By focusing on both the lowest and highest recorded temperatures, it helps in assessing the severity of cold and heat stress, informing studies on climate variability, extreme weather events, and their impacts on human health and agriculture. The data is available for India overall, across the same four seasonal periods as the mean temperature.

indicators.name: Annual and Monthly Rainfall
indicators.description: This metric captures the total rainfall received across India, presented both on an annual and a monthly basis. It is crucial for analyzing hydrological cycles, monitoring drought conditions, assessing water resource availability, and understanding the patterns of the critical Indian monsoon system. The data is available for individual months (Jan through Dec) and the total annual rainfall for the specified years.

indicators.name: Wetland distribution in India
indicators.description: This indicator details the spatial distribution and area of various wetland types across different States and Union Territories (UTs) of India. It categorizes wetlands into inland and coastal types, such as lakes, reservoirs, mangroves, and coral reefs, facilitating an understanding of the country's aquatic biodiversity and the health of these vital ecosystems. The data is critical for conservation planning, particularly in the context of the Ramsar Convention.

indicators.name: Number and Area of Wetlands
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the total count and geographical extent of wetlands in each State and UT of India, classified by size (greater than or less than 0.1 ha). It offers a concise numerical overview of India's wetland resources, supporting state-level environmental assessments and highlighting the spatial variation in wetland abundance and concentration.

indicators.name: Water Sheds in India
indicators.description: This comprehensive indicator provides data on India's watersheds, including their area, number, and associated hydraulic structures like dams, barrages, weirs, anicuts, lifts, and powerhouses. The data is further segmented by major river systems and sub-basins, offering a foundational view for water resource management, irrigation planning, and flood control within specific river catchment areas.

River Length: West flowing rivers from Tapi to Tadri
East flowing rivers between Pennar and Kanyakumari
East flowing rivers between Mahanadi and Pennar
West flowing rivers from Tadri to Kanyakumari
Minor rivers draining into Myanmar and Bangladesh
West flowing rivers of Kutch and Saurashtra including Luni

Sub Basin: Kali Sindh and others up to Confluence with Parbati
Upstream of Gomti confluence to Muzaffarnagar
Kynchiang and other south flowing rivers
East flowing rivers between Godavari & Krishna
East flowing rivers between Krishna & Pennar
Mangpui Lui and others Sub Basin

indicators.name: Catchment Area of major River Basins
indicators.description: This indicator provides the total catchment area (in square kilometers) for India's major river basins, offering a fundamental measure of the geographical extent from which each river system collects its water. It is essential for large-scale hydrological modeling, basin-wise water resource planning, and understanding the scale of major river ecosystems.

River: Area of North Ladakh not draining into Indus
WFR of Kutch & Saurashtra including Luni
Area of inland drainage in Rajasthan
Minor rivers draining into Myanmar & Bangladesh

indicators.name: Length of Coastline and Coastal Population of India
indicators.description: This metric provides the total coastline length for coastal States and UTs, coupled with the corresponding coastal population. It is vital for planning coastal zone management, assessing vulnerability to sea-level rise and cyclones, and directing socio-economic development initiatives for communities dependent on marine resources.

Sub Indicator: Coastal State Wise Population of India

indicators.name: Occurrence of Major Soils in India
indicators.description: This indicator details the distribution of major soil types (e.g., Alluvial, Black, Red, Desert soils) across India, presenting the data both in terms of total area (Mha) and as a percentage of the total landmass. This information is crucial for agricultural planning, understanding land degradation patterns, and conducting national ecological assessments.

indicators.name: Category-wise distribution of land degradation in different States of India
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the extent of land degradation in different States, categorizing the degradation type, such as water erosion, wind erosion, salinisation, and acidification. Available for specific years, it enables temporal comparison and helps policymakers prioritize remedial measures to combat desertification and soil health decline.

indicators.name: Area under land use and land cover classes in India
indicators.description: This indicator offers a high-level overview of the total area allocated to different land use and land cover classes across all of India. It helps monitor changes in land utilization patterns, which is essential for national planning, assessing forest and agricultural expansion, and understanding human-induced landscape modifications.

indicators.name: State-wise area by land cover classes
indicators.description: This indicator breaks down the total land area for each State and UT into detailed land cover classes (e.g., Cropland, Forest, Built-up, Wetlands), often with sub-categories. It provides a granular view of how land is utilized and managed at the state level, supporting local resource management and land-use policy formation.

indicators.name: List of ramsar sties in india
indicators.description: This indicator lists India's Ramsar Sites (Wetlands of International Importance), including the date of designation and the area (Sq. Km). It serves as a registry for globally recognized conservation areas, facilitating the monitoring of efforts to protect these critical wetland ecosystems.

indicators.name: Terrestrial Protected Areas
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the number and area of officially designated Terrestrial Protected Areas (National Parks and Wildlife Sanctuaries) by State and UT, along with their percentage coverage of the state's total area. It is a key measure of biodiversity conservation efforts and the extent of protected lands in India.

Sub Indicator: National Parks in % of State Area
Wildlife Sanctuaries in % of State Area

indicators.name: Faunal diversity in India and the world
indicators.description: This indicator presents a comparative overview of the total number of faunal species in India versus the world, segmented by major taxonomic phylum (e.g., Chordata, Arthropoda) and specific ecosystem groups (marine, freshwater, soil). It is vital for assessing India's contribution to global biodiversity and prioritizing species conservation strategies.

Sub Indicator: Total number of marine faunal species of world
Total number of marine faunal species in India
Number of species in India under other groups Freshwater
Number of species in India under other groups Indian Mangrove System
Number of species in India under other groups Estuarine Ecosystem
Number of species in India under other groups Soil Ecosystem
Total number of faunal species of world
Total number of faunal species in India

indicators.name: Category -wise status summary of plants at global level
indicators.description: This indicator summarizes the conservation status of plant species at a global level, based on the IUCN Red List versions over time. The status is categorized by risk (Extinct, Critically Endangered, Vulnerable, etc.), serving as a global benchmark for plant conservation and extinction risk analysis.

Risk Status: Least Concern (includes Lower Risk & least concern).

indicators.name: State-wise Forest Area
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the geographical area officially recorded as forest in each State and UT over various years, sourced from India's forest reports. It is a primary measure of forest land extent, distinct from 'forest cover' which is based on canopy density, and is essential for administrative and legal forestry planning.

indicators.name: Forest Cover in India under various forest classes
indicators.description: This indicator details the area and percentage of India's geographical area covered by forest, categorized by canopy density into Very Dense Forest, Moderately Dense Forest, and Open Forest. This is a critical ecological measure for monitoring forest health, carbon sequestration potential, and deforestation trends at the national level.

indicators.name: Forest Cover
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the actual forest cover in square kilometers and its percentage of geographic area for each State and UT over multiple years. It provides state-level data on the dense, moderately dense, and open forest categories, offering a fine-grained view of regional forest changes and the impact of conservation or logging activities.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Number of forest fire detected
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the number of forest fire incidents detected, usually over a specific fire season (e.g., Nov to Jun), and segments this data by State and UT. This information is vital for fire prevention strategies, resource deployment, and assessing the risk of habitat loss and carbon emissions from forest fires.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Carbon Stock in different forest carbon pools
indicators.description: This indicator measures the total amount of carbon stored in various forest carbon pools (Above Ground Biomass (AGB), Below Ground Biomass (BGB), Dead wood, Litter, and Soil Organic Carbon (SOC)) for each State and UT. This is a key metric for calculating India's greenhouse gas inventory and assessing the role of forests in mitigating climate change.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Forest type and density wise carbon stock in different carbon pools
indicators.description: This provides a detailed breakdown of carbon stock based on both forest type (e.g., Tropical Wet Evergreen, Montane Wet Temperate) and canopy density (VDF, MDF, OF). This granular data allows for more accurate modeling of carbon dynamics and targeted forest management for enhanced carbon sequestration.

indicators.name: Tree Cover
indicators.description: This indicator specifically quantifies the area covered by trees outside of recorded forest areas, such as in urban patches, plantations, or along roads, for each State and UT. It complements 'Forest Cover' by providing a complete picture of woody vegetation across the country, highlighting the contribution of trees in non-forest lands to ecology and carbon stock.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Ambient Air Quality in cities of the country under NAMP & CAAQMS (Integrated)
indicators.description: This indicator provides air quality data for numerous cities, collected through the National Air Monitoring Programme (NAMP) and Continuous Ambient Air Quality Monitoring Stations (CAAQMS). It tracks the concentration of key pollutants like SO2, NO2, and PM_10 to assess urban air pollution levels and compliance with national standards.

indicators.name: Ambient Air Quality in major cities
indicators.description: This indicator focuses on the ambient air quality in India's major metropolitan cities, tracking the levels of SO2, NO2, and PM10 over multiple years. It facilitates historical trend analysis to monitor the effectiveness of pollution control measures in the country's largest urban centers.

indicators.name: Water Quality in Indian Rivers
indicators.description: This indicator presents the physical and chemical characteristics of water in major Indian rivers, including parameters like pH, Dissolved Oxygen (DO), Bio-chemical Oxygen Demand (BOD), and total and faecal coliform. It is essential for assessing the overall health of river ecosystems and the suitability of river water for various uses.

indicators.name: River Water Quality
indicators.description: Similar to the general 'Water Quality in Indian Rivers' indicator, this provides State-wise minimum and maximum values for key river water quality parameters (Temperature, DO, pH, Conductivity, BOD, Nitrate, and Coliform). This detailed, state-specific data enables the identification of regional hotspots of water pollution and helps in formulating localized water quality standards.

indicators.name: Status of Critically Polluted industrial clusters
indicators.description: This indicator assesses the environmental status of designated Critically Polluted Industrial Clusters (CPICs) across India, using the Comprehensive Environmental Pollution Index (CEPI) which aggregates scores for air, surface water, and groundwater pollution. It is a key tool for identifying high-priority areas for environmental regulation and remedial action.

Area: Nazafgarh drain basin (including Anand Parvat, Naraina, Okhla and  Wazirpur), Delhi

indicators.name: Status of Ambient Noise Level in Metropolitan Cities
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the ambient noise levels (in dB A) in metropolitan cities, segmented by day, night, and 24-hour averages, and monitored at various sensitive, residential, commercial, and industrial locations. This data is used to assess noise pollution and monitor compliance with prescribed noise standards.

indicators.name: Mineral Reserves and Resources
indicators.description: This indicator provides a national inventory of geological reserves and resources for various non-fuel minerals (metallic and non-metallic) in India. The data is categorized by 'Reserve,' 'Remaining Resources,' and 'Total Resources,' which is crucial for long-term planning of the mining sector and national resource security.

Minerals Metal: Platinum gp. of metals (PGM) in tonnes of metal contained

indicators.name: Production of Minerals
indicators.description: This indicator measures the annual quantity of production for various fuel, metallic, and non-metallic minerals in India. Tracking production volume over time is critical for assessing the vitality of the mining sector, informing mineral policy, and calculating the industry's contribution to the national economy.

indicators.name: Import of Ores and Minerals
indicators.description: This indicator details the quantity and value (in Rs.'000) of different ores and minerals imported into India. It is a vital measure of India's reliance on foreign sources for raw materials, supporting trade policy analysis and national resource planning.

indicators.name: Export of Ores and Minerals (including re-export)
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the quantity and value (in Rs.'000) of ores and minerals exported from India, including re-exports. It helps in assessing the export potential of India's mineral resources and understanding the country's position in global mineral trade.

indicators.name: Inventory of geological reserves of coal by type
indicators.description: This indicator provides the total geological reserves of coal in India, classified by coal type (e.g., Prime coking, Non-coking) and resource certainty (Proved, Indicated, Inferred). This is crucial for energy policy, prioritizing mining operations, and ensuring the long-term supply of this key fuel source.

indicators.name: Inventory of geological reserves of coal
indicators.description: This indicator details the State-wise geological reserves of coal, categorized by area (Gondwana and Tertiary Coal Fields) and resource certainty (Proved, Indicated, Inferred). It supports regional energy planning and resource allocation for coal mining projects.

indicators.name: Inventory of geological reserve of Lignite
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the State-wise geological reserves of lignite (a lower-grade coal) in India, categorized by resource certainty (Proved, Indicated, Inferred). This is important for power generation planning, especially in States where lignite is a locally significant energy source.

indicators.name: Total Primary Supply of Coal & Lignite
indicators.description: This indicator measures the total annual primary supply of coal and lignite in India, factoring in domestic production, imports, exports, and changes in stock. It provides a comprehensive view of the national availability of these key fossil fuels for energy generation and industrial use.

indicators.name: Power Supply Position
indicators.description: This indicator provides a snapshot of the electricity supply and demand balance for various States/UTs and regional zones. It tracks energy requirements, energy supplied, energy not supplied (shortfall), peak demand, and peak met, which are crucial for assessing the reliability and adequacy of the power grid.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Annual gross generation of power by source and by sector
indicators.description: This indicator details the total electricity generated annually in India, broken down by energy source (Hydro, Thermal, Nuclear, Renewable) and producing sector. This is essential for monitoring the national energy mix, tracking progress toward renewable energy targets, and analyzing the environmental impact of power generation.

indicators.name: Import and Export of Electricity
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual volume of electricity imported from and exported to neighboring countries, resulting in the net import/export. This data is important for understanding the stability of India's grid and its energy trade relationship with other nations.

indicators.name: Land Use Classification
indicators.description: This indicator provides a traditional nine-fold classification of land use at the State and All India level, including Net Area Sown, Forest, Barren and Unculturable Land, etc. It is foundational for agricultural and land use planning, monitoring the overall structure of land utilization in the country.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

Land Use Sub Category: Land under misc. tree crops & groves (not incl. in net area sown)

indicators.name: Net area irrigated from different sources and gross irrigated area
indicators.description: This indicator measures the area of land irrigated from various sources (canals, tanks, tube-wells, etc.) and the gross irrigated area (including area irrigated more than once). This is a critical metric for assessing the health of the agricultural sector, monitoring water resource utilization for irrigation, and evaluating water-use efficiency.

indicators.name: State-wise area under organic farming (Registered under accredited certification bodies)
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the area under certified organic farming for each State, distinguishing between organic area, conversion area, and wild collection. It tracks the progress and adoption of sustainable agricultural practices across India.

indicators.name: Value of Output - Forestry (At Current Prices)
indicators.description: This indicator measures the monetary value of total output from the forestry and logging sector at current market prices for different States. It is a key economic indicator of the sector's contribution to the Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

indicators.name: Value of Output - Industrial Wood (At Current Prices)
indicators.description: This indicator calculates the monetary value of industrial wood production (used for construction, furniture, pulp, etc.) at current market prices, supporting economic analysis of the industrial component of the forestry sector.

indicators.name: Value of Output - Fuelwood(At Current Pric
indicators.description: This indicator measures the monetary value of fuelwood production (used for energy purposes) at current market prices, which is important for understanding the energy profile and consumption patterns of households and industries.

indicators.name: Value of Output - Non-Timber Forest Products (At Current Prices)
indicators.description: This indicator calculates the monetary value of Non-Timber Forest Products (NTFPs) (e.g., honey, medicinal plants, lac) at current market prices, providing an economic measure of the importance of these resources, often critical for the livelihoods of forest-dwelling communities.

indicators.name: Area under major crops
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the total land area (in hectares) dedicated to the cultivation of major crops (foodgrains, oilseeds, sugarcane, cotton) in India. It is a fundamental input for agricultural planning, food security analysis, and crop yield forecasting.

indicators.name: Production of major crops
indicators.description: This indicator measures the total output (in metric tonnes) of major crops in India. It is the primary metric for assessing national food security, agricultural productivity, and the performance of the farming sector.

indicators.name: Production of Biofertilizers
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the annual production volume of biofertilizers (in metric tonnes for carrier-based and KL for liquid-based) across different States and regional zones. This data reflects the adoption and availability of eco-friendly alternatives to chemical fertilizers.

indicators.name: Capacity and production of insecticides
indicators.description: This indicator provides the installed capacity and actual production volume of various technical grade pesticides and insecticides in India. It is used to monitor the chemical industry's output, assess the availability of crop protection chemicals, and evaluate potential environmental risks associated with their use.

indicators.name: Consumption, Production and Import of Fertilisers
indicators.description: This indicator provides a national-level summary of the consumption, domestic production, and import of key chemical fertilizers (Nitrogen, Phosphorous, Potassium) over several decades. It is vital for agricultural policy, subsidy planning, and understanding the country's dependence on fertilizer imports.

Sub Indicator: Cost & Freight Value of Imported Urea(Rs Cr.)

indicators.name: Nutrient-wise consumption of Fertilizers
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the consumption of Nitrogen, Phosphorous, and Potassium (NPK) fertilizers by State and regional zone. This granular data helps in assessing soil nutrient balance, promoting balanced fertilization, and evaluating the environmental impact of chemical fertilizer use at a regional level.

indicators.name: Consumption of Chemical Pesticides in India
indicators.description: This indicator details the total consumption of chemical pesticides (in MT of technical grade) in India, segmented by State and Union Territory. This is crucial for monitoring pesticide load in the environment and assessing the risks associated with chemical pest control in agriculture.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Consumption of Pesticides (Technical Grade Material)
indicators.description: This indicator specifically tracks the total consumption of technical grade pesticide material at the national level. It is a direct measure of the amount of active chemical ingredient being used, offering a high-level view of chemical intensity in Indian agriculture.

indicators.name: Consumption of bio pesticides formulation
indicators.description: This indicator measures the consumption volume of bio-pesticide formulations across different States and UTs. It is used to monitor the growth and adoption of biological pest control methods as a sustainable alternative to chemical pesticides.

indicators.name: Import of Agricultural Products
indicators.description: This indicator details the quantity and value (in Cr) of various agricultural commodities imported into India. It is crucial for analyzing India's food trade balance, import dependencies, and the impact of trade policies on the domestic agricultural market.

indicators.name: Export of Agricultural Products
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the quantity and value (in Cr) of agricultural commodities exported from India. It helps in assessing the competitiveness of Indian farm produce on the global market and monitoring the performance of the agricultural export sector.

indicators.name: Livestock population in India
indicators.description: This indicator provides the total population count for various livestock species (Cattle, Buffaloes, Sheep, Goats, Poultry, etc.) in India, based on various livestock censuses. It is a fundamental dataset for the animal husbandry sector, supporting policy related to dairy, meat production, and animal resource management.

indicators.name: Number of animals slaughtered and Quantity of Meat Production
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the number of animals slaughtered and the resulting quantity of meat production (in '000 tons) by State and animal species. It is a key metric for the meat and poultry industries, supporting food supply analysis and animal welfare monitoring.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Import and Export of Livestock & Marine Products
indicators.description: This indicator summarizes the total import and export value for broad categories of livestock and marine products. It is essential for understanding the overall trade dynamics of India's animal and fisheries sectors.

Livestock Marine Products: Dairy and Poultry Products and Honey

indicators.name: Fish Production-India
indicators.description: This indicator provides the total volume of fish production in India, segregated into marine (sea-based) and inland (aquaculture and freshwater) components. This is the main metric for the fisheries sector, supporting food security, resource management, and economic analysis.

indicators.name: Fish Production
indicators.description: This indicator details the State-wise total fish production volume, which is crucial for regional fisheries planning, monitoring resource health in coastal and inland regions, and assessing the contribution of fisheries to state-level economies.

indicators.name: Water availability in India
indicators.description: This indicator provides a high-level summary of India's water resources, including average annual precipitation, total water availability, utilizable water resources (surface and groundwater), and per capita water availability. It is the core national metric for water resource management and planning.

Sub Indicator: Per Capita Water Availability for population in cubic metres

indicators.name: Water resources -Basinwise
indicators.description: This indicator provides basin-specific estimates of water resources, including both total average annual availability and utilisable water potential for India's major river basins. The inclusion of projected demand for the years 2025 and 2050 makes it a crucial tool for long-term water security planning.

River: Area of North Ladakh not draining into Indus
WFR of Kutch & Saurashtra including Luni
Area of inland drainage in Rajasthan
Minor rivers draining into Myanmar & Bangladesh

indicators.name: Projected Water Demand in India
indicators.description: This indicator presents forecasts for water demand in India for key sectors (Irrigation, Drinking Water, Industry, Energy) for future years (2025 and 2050), often providing low and high estimates. It is essential for identifying potential water stress and developing sustainable water allocation policies.

indicators.name: Water flow in stream
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the average, minimum, and maximum water flow in specific river basins during the monsoon, non-monsoon, and annual periods. This data is critical for hydrological studies, flood forecasting, and managing water releases from reservoirs.

River: East Flowing Rivers from Mahanandi to Pennar
East Flowing Rivers from Pennar to Kanyakumari
West Flowing Rivers Tapi from to Tadri
West Flowing Rivers from Tadri to Kanyakumari
WFR of Kutch, Saurashtra Including Luni

indicators.name: Basin- Wise dynamic ground water resources
indicators.description: This indicator provides a detailed breakdown of groundwater resource dynamics for major river basins, including annual recharge, annual extraction for various uses (irrigation, domestic, industrial), and the stage of extraction. It is key to assessing groundwater sustainability and regulating extraction.

Sub Indicator: Recharge Due to Rainfall during monsoon Season
Recharge Due to Other Sources during monsoon Season
Extraction for Domestic and Industrial Needs
Total Annual Extraction for all needs
Projected Demand for Domestic needs as on Year 2025

Basin: Area of North Ladakh not draining into Indus Basin
Drainage Area of Lakshadweep Islands Basin
East flowing rivers between Godavari and Krishna Basin
East flowing rivers between Krishna and Pennar Basin
East flowing rivers between Mahanadi and Godavari Basin
East flowing rivers between Pennar and Cauvery Basin
East flowing rivers South of Cauvery Basin
Minor rivers draining into Bangladesh Basin
Minor rivers draining into Myanmar Basin
West flowing rivers of Kutch and Saurashtra including Luni Basin
West flowing rivers South of Tapi Basin

indicators.name: Ground water resources
indicators.description: This indicator provides a State-wise balance sheet of groundwater resources, detailing the components of annual recharge (rainfall, other sources), total annual extraction, and the 'Stage of Ground Water Development' (as a percentage). It is essential for monitoring and managing the country's finite groundwater reserves.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

Sub Indicator: Recharge Due to Rainfall during monsoon Season
Recharge Due to Other Sources during monsoon Season
Recharge Due to Rainfall during non-monsoon Season
Recharge Due to Other Sources during non-monsoon Season
Projected Demand for Domestic and Industrial uses upto 2025
Ground Water availability for future irrigation

indicators.name: Basin-wise Storage Status of Reservoirs of the Country
indicators.description: This indicator provides a high-level snapshot of the storage capacity and current water level in major reservoirs categorized by river basin. It is crucial for assessing water security, particularly for irrigation and power generation, and for managing inter-basin water transfers.

indicators.name: Storage Status of Reservoirs of the Country
indicators.description: This indicator details the number and total live capacity of reservoirs monitored, along with their current storage levels as a percentage of full capacity, segmented by State. It helps in the short-term management of water releases for flood control, irrigation, and drinking water supply.

Sub Indicator: Storage as % of Live Capacity at FRL

indicators.name: River basin-wise catchment area, average water resources potential and utilisable water resources potential
indicators.description: This indicator summarizes key hydrological parameters for each river basin: catchment area, average annual availability, and utilisable surface water resources. This provides a holistic view for major river systems, foundational for large-scale water policy and infrastructure planning.

River: Area of North Ladakh not draining into Indus
WFR of Kutch & Saurashtra including Luni
Area of inland drainage in Rajasthan
Minor rivers draining into Myanmar & Bangladesh

indicators.name: Greenhouse gas emission by source and removal by sinks from India
indicators.description: This indicator details India's national inventory of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and removal by sinks (like forests), including gases likeCO2, CH4, and N2O. It is the primary metric for tracking India's contribution to climate change and its compliance with international environmental commitments.

indicators.name: Consumption of Ozone Depleting Substances (ODSs) and Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) in India
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the consumption volume of various Ozone Depleting Substances (ODSs) and their common replacements, Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), in India. This data is essential for monitoring compliance with the Montreal Protocol and its Kigali Amendment for phasing down these chemicals.

indicators.name: Summary of Sewage Management
indicators.description: This indicator summarizes the State-wise status of sewage management, including the total sewage generation (in MLD), the capacity and utilization of existing Sewage Treatment Plants (STPs), and the resulting treatment gap. It is a critical metric for assessing the health of urban and rural sanitation infrastructure.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

Sub Indicator: Existing STP (Capacity in MLD and No.)
Capacity Utlization as Shown in data (in MLD)

indicators.name: Status of grossly polluting industries discharging their effluents into rivers and lakes
indicators.description: This indicator monitors the compliance status (Complying, Closed, Not Complying) of industrial units designated as 'Grossly Polluting Industries' (GPIs) that discharge effluents into rivers and lakes. This is a key enforcement metric for environmental regulators to track industrial water pollution control.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Municipal Solid Waste Generation in India
indicators.description: This indicator provides the State-wise status of Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) management, quantifying the total quantity generated, collected, treated, and landfilled (in TPD). It also reports the number of operational composting and landfill facilities, which is essential for urban planning and waste management policy.

indicators.name: Municipal Solid Waste Generation in Metro Cities / State Capitals
indicators.description: This indicator focuses on the waste generation volume (in TPD) in India's major cities and state capitals. Tracking this data is vital for large urban centers to plan and manage their complex waste infrastructure, especially given high population densities.

indicators.name: Amount of Waste Generated by Waste Category
indicators.description: This indicator provides the State-wise generation volumes for specific non-MSW waste streams, including Hazardous Waste (MTA), Bio-Medical Waste (kg/day), and Plastic Waste (TPA). This disaggregation is important for specialized waste management strategies and environmental regulation.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Details on Hazardous Waste generation
indicators.description: This indicator provides a detailed breakdown of hazardous waste generation by State, categorized by disposal method (Landfillable, Incinerable, Recyclable, Utilizable). It helps in tracking the proper disposal and treatment of industrial hazardous waste as mandated by regulations.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

Sub Indicator: Quantity of Hazardous waste generated as per Annual Return within the state/UT (MT)

indicators.name: Status of Bio-medical Waste Generation and its Management
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the generation and management of Bio-medical Waste (BMW) by State, including the total quantity generated, the number of healthcare facilities, and the utilization of Common Bio-medical Waste Treatment Facilities (CBWTFs). This is crucial for controlling the spread of disease and ensuring public health.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

Sub Indicator: Total Quantity of BMW Treated and Disposed (kg/day)

indicators.name: Status on Imports & Exports of Hazardous Waste
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual quantity of hazardous waste imported and exported by States, which is necessary to monitor compliance with international agreements on transboundary movement of hazardous materials (like the Basel Convention).

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Status of Industrial Waste Water Treatment Plants
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the number and total capacity (in MLD) of existing Common Effluent Treatment Plants (CETPs) by State. It is a measure of the collective infrastructure available for treating wastewater from industrial clusters before discharge.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Average Number of Heat Wave Days reported during the Summer Season
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the average number of heat wave days reported by specific States during the summer season over several years. This data is crucial for public health warnings, disaster preparedness, and assessing the regional impact of climate-related temperature extremes.

indicators.name: Average Number of Cold Wave Days Reported during the Winter Season (December of Previous Year to February of Current Year)
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the average number of cold wave days reported by specific States during the winter season. Similar to heat waves, this is vital for monitoring public health risks, energy demand forecasting, and disaster response.

indicators.name: Number of Cyclonic Storms formed over the North Indian Ocean
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the number of cyclonic storms formed over the North Indian Ocean, broken down by month and year. This time series data is essential for assessing climate variability, improving forecasting models, and planning for coastal disaster risk reduction.

indicators.name: Major Earthquakes in India
indicators.description: This indicator is a historical record of major earthquakes in India, providing the date, region, and magnitude of significant seismic events. It is a critical reference for seismic hazard mapping, building codes, and disaster preparedness planning.

indicators.name: Damage due to Natural Extreme Events in India
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the national-level damage caused by natural extreme events (e.g., floods, cyclones), tracking metrics like human lives lost, cattle lost, houses damaged, and cropped areas affected. This is vital for macroeconomic impact assessment and disaster relief planning.

indicators.name: Damage due to Natural Extreme Events
indicators.description: This indicator provides a State-wise breakdown of the damage caused by natural extreme events, using metrics like human lives lost, cattle lost, houses damaged, and cropped areas affected. This geographical disaggregation supports local disaster management and relief efforts.

indicators.name: Number of Deaths due to Forces of Nature
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the number and percentage of total deaths attributed to various forces of nature (e.g., Flood, Lightening, Heat Stroke, Cyclone). This data is used by public health and disaster management agencies to prioritize risk areas and prevention campaigns.

indicators.name: Government Expenditure on account of Natural Calamities
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the actual, revised, and budget estimates of State government expenditure allocated for relief and rehabilitation efforts following natural calamities. This is a key financial metric for assessing the fiscal burden of disasters on state budgets.

indicators.name: Houses, Households and Population in India
indicators.description: This indicator provides fundamental demographic and housing data for India, including the number of houses, households, and population size, categorized by rural, urban, and total areas. This baseline census data is essential for social and urban planning, and for calculating per capita environmental metrics.

indicators.name: Coastal Fishing Population in India
indicators.description: This indicator details the demographic and infrastructural aspects of the coastal fishing community, including coastal length, number of landing centers, fishing villages, fisherfolk population, and the count of Below Poverty Line (BPL) families. This data is critical for marine resource management and social welfare schemes for fishing communities.

indicators.name: Distribution of Households by Major Source of Drinking Water
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the percentage distribution of households across India by their major source of drinking water (e.g., Piped Water, Tube Well, Bottled Water), disaggregated by rural and urban areas and different survey rounds (NFHS). It is a key metric for monitoring progress towards safe drinking water access.

Source Drinking Water: Piped Water / Tap/ Public Tap/ Standpipe
Surface Water (River/ Canal/ Lake/ Tank/ Pond)

indicators.name: Percentage of households getting safe and adequate drinking water within premises through pipe water supply (Rural)
indicators.description: This indicator specifically measures the percentage of rural households with tap connections from a piped water supply within their premises. It is a direct and important metric for evaluating the success of rural water schemes like the Jal Jeevan Mission.

Sub Indicator: Total Household Tap connection through PWS

indicators.name: Percentage of households getting safe and adequate drinking water within premises through pipe water supply (Urban)
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the percentage of urban households with tap connections from a piped water supply within their premises. This is crucial for assessing urban infrastructure development and the coverage of public water supply systems in cities.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

Sub Indicator: No. of urban Households with Household tap Connection

indicators.name: Distribution of Households with Access to Sanitation
indicators.description: This indicator provides the distribution of households across India based on their access to toilet facilities (within or outside premises), categorized by rural, urban, and total areas. It is a core metric for monitoring the progress of sanitation coverage in the country.

Sub Indicator: With Toilet of Any Type (Within the Premises)
Without Toilet of Any Type (Within the Premises)

indicators.name: Percentage distribution of Households by sanitation facilities
indicators.description: This indicator provides a detailed breakdown of the type of sanitation facility used by households (Improved, Shared, Unimproved, No facility/open defecation), categorized by State and rural/urban areas (NFHS data). This detailed information helps in targeting specific sanitation challenges.

Sub Indicator: No facility/ uses open space/ field

indicators.name: Number of Towns/ Cities Reporting Slums and Percentage of Slum Population
indicators.description: This indicator provides a census-based count of the number of towns and cities reporting slums and the percentage of the total urban population residing in slums. This is critical for urban planning, housing policy, and socio-economic development initiatives.

Sub Indicator: % of slum population to total urban population

indicators.name: Percentage of Districsts achieving Open Defecation free (ODF) target
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the cumulative percentage of districts in each State that have officially achieved the Open Defecation Free (ODF) status over time. It is a key performance indicator for the national sanitation mission, Swachh Bharat Abhiyan.

indicators.name: Proportion of households having access to toilet facility
indicators.description: This indicator specifically tracks the proportion of rural households with access to toilet facilities over several years. It is a fundamental metric for monitoring the reach of sanitation programs in rural India.

indicators.name: Population connected to wastewater collecting system
indicators.description: This indicator provides a breakdown of households by their connection to a wastewater collecting system (Closed drainage, Open drainage, No drainage) and their access to bathing facilities. It helps assess the penetration and effectiveness of urban and rural wastewater infrastructure.

Sub Indicator: Number of households having bathing facility (Bathroom) within the premises
Number of households having bathing facility (Enclosure without roof) within the premises
Number of households having no bathing facility within the premises

Waste water outlet connected to Open drainage
Waste water outlet connected to No drainage

indicators.name: Slum households by source and location of drinking water
indicators.description: This indicator focuses on the source and location of drinking water for households residing in slums, providing data for various sources (Treated Tap, Untreated Tap, Hand pump, Well). This information is crucial for directing basic utility services and improving living conditions in informal urban settlements.

Sub Indicator: Number of households (Hhs) have source of drinking water - Tap (Treated Source)
Number of households (Hhs) have source of drinking water - Tap (Untreated Source)

Number of households (Hhs) have source of drinking water - All Others

indicators.name: All india weighted average rate of sale of power (WARSP) from conventional power generating stations
indicators.description: This indicator calculates the national weighted average rate (price) for the sale of power from conventional (non-renewable) sources. It is an important economic metric for utility regulation, energy tariff setting, and financial performance analysis of the power sector.

indicators.name: Statistics related to Road Transport
indicators.description: This indicator provides national-level data on the road network length (National/State Highways, Surfaced/Unsurfaced), number of registered vehicles, revenue generated from road transport, and the volume of goods and passenger movement. It is essential for transportation policy, infrastructure planning, and economic assessment of the logistics sector.

Sub Indicator: Goods and passenger movement by road transport

indicators.name: Status of registered Motor Vehicles
indicators.description: This indicator details the State-wise number of registered motor vehicles, categorized into Transport and Non-Transport vehicles. This data is key for monitoring the growth of vehicular traffic, assessing pollution load from the transport sector, and planning for road infrastructure and safety.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Number of passengers carried by state road transport undertakings
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the total number of passengers transported annually by State Road Transport Undertakings (SRTUs). It is a direct measure of the scale and utilization of public bus transport services across the country.

indicators.name: Cases & Deaths - Cholera
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual number of reported cases and deaths due to Cholera by State. This data is a key public health metric, often correlated with the quality of drinking water and sanitation.

indicators.name: Cases and deaths - Acute Diarrhoeal Disease
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual number of reported cases and deaths due to Acute Diarrhoeal Disease (ADD) by State. ADD is a major public health concern, especially among children, and this data is vital for monitoring water-borne diseases.

indicators.name: Cases and deaths - Enteric Fever (Typhoid)
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual number of reported cases and deaths due to Enteric Fever (Typhoid) by State. Typhoid is another major water-borne disease, and this data is crucial for assessing environmental hygiene and public health outcomes.

indicators.name: Cases and Deaths - Viral Hepatitis
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual number of reported cases and deaths due to Viral Hepatitis by State. This data is important for monitoring infectious disease outbreaks and the effectiveness of public health interventions.

indicators.name: Cases and Deaths - Acute Respiratory Infection
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual number of reported cases and deaths due to Acute Respiratory Infection (ARI) by State. ARI is strongly linked to air pollution and household smoke exposure, making this data an environmental health indicator.

indicators.name: Cases and deaths - Malaria
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual number of reported cases (including PF cases) and deaths due to Malaria by State. This is a critical public health metric for monitoring vector-borne diseases and the efficacy of control programs.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Cases and death - Dengue
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual number of reported cases and deaths due to Dengue by State. Dengue is a rapidly increasing vector-borne disease, and this data is crucial for forecasting outbreaks and planning public health responses.

indicators.name: Cases - Chikungunya fever
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual number of reported cases of Chikungunya fever by State. This is important for monitoring the spread of this mosquito-borne viral disease across the country.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Cases and deaths - Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES)
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual number of reported cases and deaths due to Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES), distinguishing between AES and Japanese Encephalitis JE cases/deaths, by State. This is a critical public health indicator for a disease often associated with water logging and poor sanitation.

State: Daman and Diu and Dadra Nagar Haveli

indicators.name: Expenditure on Centrally Sponsored Schemes for Protection of Environment
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual governmental expenditure on key centrally sponsored schemes for environment protection, such as the National Mission for a Green India and National River Conservation Programme. It measures the financial commitment to national environmental goals.

Scheme: National Mission for a Green India
Conservation of Natural Resources and Ecosystems

indicators.name: Annual Government Expenditure on Environmental Protection
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the total annual governmental expenditure on environmental protection at the All India level. It provides a high-level measure of the government's financial investment in protecting and preserving the environment.

indicators.name: Annual Corporate Expenditure on Environment Protection- Conservation of Natural Resources Sector
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual expenditure by Indian corporations on environmental protection activities focused on the Conservation of Natural Resources Sector, as part of their Corporate Social Responsibility CSR or other initiatives.

indicators.name: Annual Corporate Expenditure on Environment Protection- Agro Forestry Sector
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual expenditure by Indian corporations on environmental protection activities focused on the Agro Forestry Sector.

indicators.name: Annual Corporate Expenditure on Environment Protection- Environmental Sustainability sector
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the annual expenditure by Indian corporations on environmental protection activities focused on the Environmental Sustainability Sector.

indicators.name: Annual Corporate Expenditure on Environment Protection- Across 3 sectors
indicators.description: This indicator aggregates the total annual corporate expenditure on environmental protection across the three specified sectors: Conservation of Natural Resources, Agro Forestry, and Environmental Sustainability.

indicators.name: Subsidies (including Environment-related Subsidies) under Indian Budget
indicators.description: This indicator details the financial outlays (Budget, Revised, and Actual estimates) for various government subsidies, including environmentally relevant subsidies like those for fertilizers and petroleum. It helps in assessing the magnitude and allocation of subsidies and their potential impact on the environment.

indicators.name: Number of Students pursuing environment-related higher education at Ph.D.,M.Phil. & Post Graduate Level
indicators.description: This indicator quantifies the number of students enrolled in higher education (Ph.D., M.Phil., Post Graduate) in environment-related fields (e.g., Environmental Science, Forestry, Marine Engineering). This is a metric for monitoring the development of human capital in environmental disciplines.

NFHS.description: The National Family Health Survey (NFHS) is a large-scale, multi-round survey providing comprehensive data on population, health, and nutrition for India and its States/Union Territories. Conducted by the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, the survey offers critical, disaggregated insights into demographic trends, fertility rates, family planning practices, maternal and child health, mortality rates, and the nutritional status of both children and adults. NFHS data is fundamental for evidence-based policymaking, program development, monitoring the progress of national health goals, and tracking various Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) related to health and well-being. The data is typically available segregated by Rural and Urban sectors and is published on an ad-hoc basis, with the latest available rounds being NFHS-4 (2015-16) and NFHS-5 (2019-21).

indicators.name: Population and Household Profile
indicators.description: This indicator provides key statistics regarding the basic demographic and living standards of households. Metrics cover the use of improved water and sanitation facilities, access to electricity, utilization of clean fuel for cooking, and the use of iodized salt, serving as critical proxies for socio-economic development and environmental health outcomes. It also includes important demographic figures like the sex ratio at birth and the registration status of births and deaths, which are essential for population planning and civil registration completeness.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Characteristics of Adults (age 15-49 years)
indicators.description: This indicator focuses on the educational attainment and digital literacy of the prime adult population (age 15-49), differentiated by sex. It tracks the percentage of men and women who are literate, have achieved 10 or more years of schooling, and have ever used the internet. These metrics are vital for assessing progress in human capital development, gender equality in education, and the spread of digital inclusion across different states and sectors.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Marriage and Fertility
indicators.description: This indicator reports crucial data on reproductive health and demographic shifts. Key metrics include the Total Fertility Rate (TFR), which is the average number of children per woman, and measures of early marriage, such as the percentage of women and men married before the legal age. It also includes the Adolescent fertility rate, which measures births per 1,000 women aged 15-19 years. These statistics are essential for demographic forecasting, evaluating the effectiveness of family planning programs, and monitoring child protection and education policies aimed at delaying the age of marriage and first birth.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

Sub Indicator: Adolescent fertility rate for women age 15-19 years5
Men age 25-29 years married before age 21 years (%)

indicators.name: Infant and Child Mortality Rates (per 1,000 live births)
indicators.description: Infant and Child Mortality Rates (per 1,000 live births): This indicator presents primary measures of child survival, including the Neonatal Mortality Rate (deaths within 28 days of birth), Infant Mortality Rate (deaths before age one), and Under-five Mortality Rate (deaths before age five). These rates, expressed per 1,000 live births, are fundamental indicators of the overall health status of a population, the quality of maternal and child healthcare services, and the socio-economic conditions of a region.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Current Use of Family Planning Methods (currently married women age 15-49 years)
indicators.description: This indicator measures the prevalence of family planning use among married women of reproductive age. It tracks the percentage using any method (modern or traditional) and specifically details the uptake of various modern methods such as female and male sterilization, IUDs, pills, and condoms. This data is critical for monitoring the success of national family welfare programs and understanding regional preferences for different contraceptive options.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Unmet Need for Family Planning (currently married women age 15-49 years)
indicators.description: This indicator measures the percentage of married women who want to space or stop childbearing but are not currently using any family planning method. It distinguishes between the total unmet need and the specific unmet need for spacing births. High unmet need indicates gaps in the accessibility, affordability, or acceptability of family planning services, making this a crucial measure for improving public health outreach and resource allocation.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Quality of Family Planning Services
indicators.description: This indicator assesses the effectiveness and quality of service delivery within the national family planning program. Key metrics include whether current users were ever informed about the side effects of their chosen method and whether non-users were ever approached by a health worker to discuss family planning. This focuses on client-centered care and the proactive involvement of the health system in promoting informed choice and continuation of contraceptive use.

State: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu

indicators.name: Maternity Care (for last birth in the 5 years before the survey)
indicators.description: This indicator evaluates the adequacy and coverage of Antenatal Care (ANC) and Postnatal Care (PNC) services. It includes critical measures such as the mother receiving an ANC check-up in the first trimester, completing at least four ANC visits, and consuming iron folic acid supplements for 100 or more days during pregnancy. The indicator also tracks the average out-of-pocket expenditure for public facility deliveries and the receipt of financial assistance like the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), providing insight into the financial accessibility of care.

The central measure is the percentage of Institutional births (delivery in a health facility) and the percentage of births attended by skilled health personnel. It also tracks the rate of deliveries by Caesarean section, disaggregated by public and private health facilities, which is used to monitor medical practices and potential over-medicalization of births.

indicators.name: Child Vaccinations and Vitamin A Supplementation
indicators.description: This indicator monitors the national immunization program by measuring the percentage of children aged 12-23 months who are fully immunized with all basic vaccinations (BCG, measles, 3 doses of polio and DPT/Penta). It also tracks the coverage of specific vaccines (e.g., Rotavirus) and the delivery of essential micronutrients like Vitamin A supplementation. This data is vital for assessing community protection against infectious diseases and the reach of preventative child health services.

indicators.name: Treatment of Childhood Diseases (children under age 5 years)
indicators.description: This indicator measures the prevalence and management of common childhood illnesses, specifically diarrhoea and Acute Respiratory Infection (ARI), in the two weeks preceding the survey. It tracks the percentage of sick children who were taken to a health provider and the proportion of children with diarrhoea who received appropriate treatment, such as Oral Rehydration Salts (ORS) and zinc. This is critical for assessing health system responsiveness to childhood morbidity.

indicators.name: Child Feeding Practices and Nutritional Status of Children
indicators.description: This indicator provides a comprehensive view of child nutrition. It covers key feeding practices like exclusive breastfeeding for children under six months and the introduction of solid/semi-solid foods. Crucially, it provides the four main measures of malnutrition: stunting (height-for-age), wasting (weight-for-height), underweight (weight-for-age), and the percentage of children who are overweight. This data is paramount for framing nutrition policies and evaluating programs aimed at combating both under- and over-nutrition.

indicators.name: Nutritional Status of Adults (age 15-49 years)
indicators.description: This indicator assesses the nutritional status of adults using anthropometric measures, differentiated by sex. It tracks the percentage of men and women who are underweight (BMI < 18.5 kg/m^2) and those who are overweight or obese (BMI â‰¥ 25.0 kg/m^2). Additionally, it includes the prevalence of a high-risk waist-to-hip ratio, which is a measure of central obesity and associated health risks. This helps monitor the double burden of malnutrition in the adult population.

indicators.name: Anaemia among Children and Adults
indicators.description: This indicator provides the prevalence of anaemia across various population groups, including children, adolescent boys and girls, and women (pregnant, non-pregnant, and all women of reproductive age). Anaemia is diagnosed based on low haemoglobin levels (e.g., <11.0 g/dl for children) and is a key public health challenge often linked to poor nutrition and iron deficiency.

indicators.name: Blood Sugar Level among Adults (age 15 years and above)
indicators.description: This indicator measures the prevalence of elevated blood sugar levels, a primary indicator for diabetes risk, among men and women aged 15 and above. It reports the percentage with high (141-160 mg/dl) and very high (>160 mg/dl) blood sugar, or those currently taking medicine to control it. This is a vital public health metric for monitoring the growing burden of non-communicable diseases.

indicators.name: Hypertension among Adults (age 15 years and above)
indicators.description: This indicator tracks the prevalence of elevated blood pressure (hypertension) among adults, segmented by sex. It reports the percentage with mildly elevated (Systolic 140-159 mm of Hg) and moderately or severely elevated (Systolic â‰¥ 160 mm of Hg) blood pressure, or those taking medication. indicators.description: This indicator measures the uptake of preventative cancer screening tests among adults, focusing on the prime target age group for early detection. It tracks whether women have ever undergone a breast examination or a screening test for cervical cancer, and whether men and women have had an oral cavity examination for oral cancer. Low screening rates indicate a gap in primary healthcare services and awareness.

indicators.description: This indicator assesses the level of awareness and accurate knowledge regarding HIV/AIDS transmission and prevention among the adult population, differentiated by sex. Key metrics include comprehensive knowledge of the disease and knowing that consistent condom use can reduce the risk of transmission. indicators.description: This composite indicator tracks multiple facets of women's autonomy and socio-economic status. Metrics include participation in household decisions, ownership of house or land, having a personal bank account or mobile phone, and being paid in cash for work. It also measures the use of hygienic methods of menstrual protection. These indicators collectively assess progress toward gender equality and women's agency.

indicators.name: Gender Based Violence (age 18-49 years)
indicators.description: This sensitive indicator provides data on the prevalence of physical and sexual violence experienced by women, primarily focusing on spousal violence (by an intimate partner). It also measures violence during pregnancy and sexual violence experienced by young women before the age of 18. EC4.description: The Economic Census (4th Edition, 1998) is a statistical product under the category of Economic Statistics, conducted by the Economic Statistics Division, Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI). It encompasses data for all of India, covering rural and urban areas across states and districts. Conducted as and when required, the 4th Economic Census serves as a foundational dataset offering a comprehensive enumeration of establishments engaged in economic activities, excluding those related to crop production and plantation. The census captures detailed information on the number of establishments and persons employed, with disaggregations by geographical location, type of ownership, sector, major activity, nature of operation, and source of finance. As a key statistical resource, it provides valuable insights into the structure and distribution of Indiaâ€™s economic establishments, particularly in the unorganized sector. The data support evidence-based planning, policy formulation, and economic research by offering a micro-level understanding of employment and enterprise patterns. The product was last updated in April 2016, and although it has no fixed base period, it forms part of a continuing effort to document Indiaâ€™s economic landscape. Comprehensive metadata and access to the dataset are available through the National Metadata Structure.

indicators.name: Perennial
indicators.description: An establishment is classified as perennial if it operates more or less continuously throughout the year. Such establishments conduct business or production activities on a regular, year-round basis, without significant seasonal interruptions. Examples include manufacturing units, retail shops, or service enterprises that remain open all year.

indicators.name: Seasonal
indicators.description: An establishment is categorized as seasonal if it operates only during a particular season or part of the year, typically influenced by climatic conditions, agricultural cycles, or demand fluctuations. These units remain closed or inactive for the rest of the year when conditions are not favorable for their operations. Examples include ice factories, sugar mills, or units engaged in processing agricultural produce that function only during harvest seasons.

EC5.description: The Economic Census 5 (2005) is a comprehensive statistical product under the category of Economic Statistics, developed and maintained by the Economic Statistics Division of the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI). It serves as a nationwide enumeration of all economic establishments, excluding those engaged in crop production and plantation activities, with a focus on both the organized and unorganized sectors. The dataset captures detailed information on the number of establishments, employment levels, and their distribution across geographical units (All India, States, Districts, Rural, and Urban areas). Key variables include the type of major activity, sector, nature of operation, ownership structure, and source of finance. Conducted as and when required, the 5th Economic Census (2005) represents a crucial reference point for assessing the structural composition and dynamics of Indiaâ€™s economic establishments. The data was last updated in April 2016, with no fixed base period applicable. As an official national data source, the Economic Census supports evidence-based policymaking and economic planning by offering a comprehensive and disaggregated view of enterprise activity across India. More information can be accessed through the National Metadata Structure.

indicators.name: Perennial
indicators.description: An establishment is classified as perennial if it operates more or less continuously throughout the year. Such establishments conduct business or production activities on a regular, year-round basis, without significant seasonal interruptions. Examples include manufacturing units, retail shops, or service enterprises that remain open all year.

indicators.name: Seasonal
indicators.description: An establishment is categorized as seasonal if it operates only during a particular season or part of the year, typically influenced by climatic conditions, agricultural cycles, or demand fluctuations. These units remain closed or inactive for the rest of the year when conditions are not favorable for their operations. Examples include ice factories, sugar mills, or units engaged in processing agricultural produce that function only during harvest seasons.

EC6.description: The Economic Census 5 (2005) is a comprehensive statistical product under the category of Economic Statistics, developed and maintained by the Economic Statistics Division of the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI). It serves as a nationwide enumeration of all economic establishments, excluding those engaged in crop production and plantation activities, with a focus on both the organized and unorganized sectors. The dataset captures detailed information on the number of establishments, employment levels, and their distribution across geographical units (All India, States, Districts, Rural, and Urban areas). Key variables include the type of major activity, sector, nature of operation, ownership structure, and source of finance. Conducted as and when required, the 5th Economic Census (2005) represents a crucial reference point for assessing the structural composition and dynamics of Indiaâ€™s economic establishments. The data was last updated in April 2016, with no fixed base period applicable. As an official national data source, the Economic Census supports evidence-based policymaking and economic planning by offering a comprehensive and disaggregated view of enterprise activity across India. More information can be accessed through the National Metadata Structure.

indicators.name: Perennial
indicators.description: An establishment is classified as perennial if it operates more or less continuously throughout the year. Such establishments conduct business or production activities on a regular, year-round basis, without significant seasonal interruptions. Examples include manufacturing units, retail shops, or service enterprises that remain open all year.
